Central Tendency.Mean: The average of all data points.
Central Tendency.Median: The middle value when data is ordered.

Measures of Dispersion.Range: The difference between the maximum and minimum values.
Measures of Dispersion.Variance: The average of the squared differences from the mean.
Measures of Dispersion.Standard Deviation: The square root of the variance.
Measures of Dispersion.Interquartile Range (IQR): The range between the first and third quartiles.
Measures of Dispersion.Mean Absolute Deviation (MAD): The average of the absolute deviations from the mean. MAD = (Σ|xi - μ|) / n
Measures of Dispersion.Coefficient of Variation (CV): A normalized measure of dispersion of a probability distribution or frequency distribution.

Measures of Correlation.Pearson Correlation Coefficient: Measures the linear relationship between two variables.
Measures of Correlation.Spearman Rank Correlation: Measures the monotonic relationship between two variables.
Measures of Correlation.Kendall Tau Correlation: Measures the ordinal association between two variables.

Z-Test.Description: Used when the population variance is known and the sample size is large (n > 30). It assesses whether the sample mean significantly differs from the population mean.

T-Test.Description: Used when the population variance is unknown or the sample size is small (n ≤ 30). It assesses whether the sample mean significantly differs from the population mean.

ANOVA-Test.Description: Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) tests differences between means of three or more groups. It checks if at least one group mean is significantly different from the others.

Chi-Square Test.Description: Used to assess the association between categorical variables. It tests whether the observed frequencies in a contingency table differ significantly from the expected frequencies.

Mann-Whitney U Test.Description: Used to determine if there is a significant difference between the distributions of two independent groups. It is a non-parametric alternative to the independent t-test.
Mann-Whitney U Test.Formula: U = min(U1, U2), where U1 and U2 are calculated based on the ranks of the data.

Wilcoxon Rank-Sum Test.Description: Another name for the Mann-Whitney U Test. It involves ranking all observations from both groups and then summing the ranks for each group.
Wilcoxon Rank-Sum Test.Formula: U = min(U1, U2), where U1 and U2 are calculated based on the ranks of the data.

Wilcoxon Signed-Rank Test.Description: Used to test for differences between paired observations. It is a non-parametric alternative to the paired t-test.
Wilcoxon Signed-Rank Test.Formula: The test statistic is the sum of the signed ranks of the differences between paired observations.

Kruskal-Wallis Test.Description: Used to test for differences between the distributions of three or more independent groups. It is a non-parametric alternative to one-way ANOVA.
Kruskal-Wallis Test.Formula: H = (12 / (N * (N + 1))) * Σ (R_i² / n_i) - 3 * (N + 1), where R_i is the sum of ranks for the i-th group, n_i is the number of observations in the i-th group, and N is the total number of observations.

Standard Error.definition: The standard error measures the variability of a sample statistic (e.g., sample mean) from the population parameter. It is calculated as the standard deviation of the sampling distribution of the statistic.

EDA.description: Exploratory Data Analysis involves summarizing the main characteristics of a dataset, often with visual methods, to uncover patterns, spot anomalies, test hypotheses, and check assumptions.

Data Visualization.Scatter Plots: Examine relationships between two continuous variables.

Descriptive Statistics.Summary Statistics: Basic measures such as mean, median, and standard deviation.
Descriptive Statistics.Frequency Distributions: Understand the distribution of categorical variables.

Data Cleaning.Identifying Outliers: Methods to detect and manage outliers.
